label: Pain trade is up
input: everyone is positioned for a dollar rally. pain trade is up in everything.
notes: 9 words. Crowding signal, not a direction call. 'Pain trade is up in everything' means: if most people are long dollar / short risk, the pain trade (the move that hurts the most people) is dollar weakening + risk assets spiking. This is a positioning observation, not a fundamental thesis. The correct interpretation: short dollar or long risk. Closest pure-play: UUP puts (dollar ETF) or DXY-PERP short on HL. Key test: does the skill recognize this as a crowding → reversal thesis, not a fundamental macro call? Does it verify the positioning claim with CFTC COT data?

expected.thesis_interpretation: crowding → mean reversion, not fundamental macro
expected.research_required: verify CFTC COT data or speculative positioning on dollar
chose_over: UUP puts (correct direction but options illiquid on dollar ETFs)
expected.should_NOT_do: take 'pain trade is up' as a bullish call and go long everything, or route to a macro ETF without verifying positioning

label: DeepSeek destroyed AI moats but Jensen is still buying
input: DeepSeek proved AI is commoditizing. margins are going to zero. but Nvidia just reported blowout earnings so clearly the market doesn't care. i want to be short the narrative but long the picks-and-shovels.
notes: Compound thesis with two conflicting legs: (1) short AI narrative/SaaS companies with AI moat claims, (2) long GPU/infrastructure despite commodity thesis. This is internally consistent (DeepSeek → more inference → more GPUs needed) but expressed confusingly. Tests: can skill decompose, resolve the apparent contradiction, and find a single expression that captures both legs? Correct answer: this is actually a Jevons Paradox thesis — cheap AI = more usage = more compute demand. The SHORT is application-layer (AI SaaS with 'AI moat' premium: PLTR at 100x revenue, AI-premium SaaS). The LONG is infrastructure. Skill should find a pair trade: short PLTR (overvalued AI narrative) / long NVDA (infrastructure beneficiary). Or: just NVDA long if skill can only express one leg.

expected.resolution: Jevons Paradox — cheap AI = more inference = more GPU demand. Contradiction resolves: short narrative premium, long infrastructure.
expected.primary_expression: long NVDA (inference demand) / short PLTR (AI narrative premium at 100x revenue)
expected.alt: NVDA long only if pair trade is too complex
expected.should_NOT_do: treat as irreconcilable contradiction and refuse to route, or ignore the short leg entirely

label: OpenAI is about to IPO and it's going to change everything
input: OpenAI IPO is going to be the biggest in history. Sam is building AGI and nobody is pricing it correctly. I want exposure.
notes: The primary subject (OpenAI) is private. No direct investment vehicle. Tests the full expression fidelity ladder. Should explore: MSFT (largest shareholder, ~49% stake worth ~$100B+ if OpenAI IPOs at $300B), then alternatives. Key insight: MSFT is interesting but 70%+ of value is NOT OpenAI — thesis alignment is diluted. Better: wait for IPO, or find alt exposure. Possibly: Anthropic is also private. Pure-play AI infra that benefits regardless of which lab wins: NVDA (all labs buy their GPUs). This is a case where the skill must honestly say 'direct exposure is impossible until IPO, here's the best proxy and why it's imperfect.'

expected.honest_flag: OpenAI is private — no direct investment vehicle
expected.proxy_option: MSFT (largest shareholder) but thesis alignment is diluted (~30% of MSFT value)
expected.alt_proxy: NVDA (all labs buy their GPUs — wins regardless of which lab wins)
expected.should_NOT_do: just say 'buy MSFT' without flagging the dilution, or pretend the IPO can be bet on directly

label: Real estate is dead — offices will never fill up again
input: real estate is dead. offices are empty. nobody is going back full time. the wfh trend is permanent and the market still hasn't priced it in.
notes: This thesis is 4 years old (post-COVID consensus). Tests whether the skill flags 'already priced in' correctly. Office REIT vacancy rates are well-documented, market has already punished BXP/VNO/SLG. The 'market still hasn't priced it in' claim is testable. Correct behavior: (1) verify whether it's actually priced in (it largely is), (2) if priced in → flag honestly and reduce conviction, (3) look for the angle that ISN'T priced in (e.g., tier-1 office in NYC is recovering vs tier-2/suburban is dead — more nuanced). May route to SLG short (suburban exposure) vs VNO as hedge, or admit the thesis is stale.

expected.honest_flag: this thesis may be largely priced in — office REIT prices already reflect WFH discount
expected.nuance_required: tier-1 NYC/SF office recovering (RTO mandates), tier-2/suburban still dying
expected.possible_routing: SLG puts (more suburban/mixed exposure) if thesis survives pricing analysis
expected.should_NOT_do: route to VNO/BXP short without checking if it's already priced in, or accept 'market hasn't priced it' without verifying
